sp.l: Nay, fie, this shameful Argument—

sp.speaker: Mr. Dep.
sp.p: I'll hear no more. Get you home to your Temple, read your Littleton, eat your Mutton, draggle year Goon, and come again (let me see) to morow Night. By that time I shall have consider'd matters, and will give you full Satisfaction in the Point.

sp.speaker: Ned St.
sp.l: On that Condition, Sir, I'm all Obedience:
I'll take my Leave, and wait your Hour of Grace▪ Exit.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dep.
sp.p: Yes, Son, I'll marry her in the morning, and give thee Satisfaction at Night.

lg.l: Young Counsellours Old Heads must never sway;
Gold in a Fathers Scales must only weigh;
Let Sons Preach Honour, Int'rest is our Play▪ Exit.

div.stage: The SCENE, An Arborage of Palms and Lawrels, consisting of Nine Arches, environ'd with Flotoons of Flowers, bound with Ribbons of Gold, and held up with Flying Cupids.
Enter Sir Dottrel, met by Jacintha led by Shackarel.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: WEll, Sir Dottrel, here's honest Shackarell has told me your whole Mind; that you are resolved to marry Jacintha, right or wrong; to take her as blind Men do Money, false or true, Brass or Silver.

sp.speaker: Sir Dott.
sp.p: And if thou hast the Conscience to cheat that Blind Man with Adulterate for Sterling, be the Sin at thy own Door.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: And then you dare venture upon me?

sp.speaker: Sir Dott.
sp.p: Dare! I must dare; for I can't live without thee.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Say you so, my Heart of Steel. Then let not your Noble Courage be cast down: For to chear up your Heart, know, to the utter Confusion of Fears and Jealousies, I am Virtuous.

sp.speaker: Sir Dott.
sp.p: Virtuous!

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: And will live and die so;
Nay, all the Affronts and Cheats I've put upon you
Have been only so many Trials of your Patience and your Constancy;
And here, before honest Shakarell, I promise you,
Sir Dottrel is the Man of the whole World
Shall make me th' happiest and best Wife in Christendom.

sp.speaker: Sir Dott.
sp.p: I am transported!

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Nay, my whole last Night's Roguery—

sp.speaker: Sir Dott.
sp.p: Oh! No more of that.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Was all but a Sham-Plot.

sp.speaker: Sir Dott.
sp.p: How! A Sham-Plot?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Betwixt your Man and me.

sp.speaker: Sir Dott.
sp.p: My Man Shakarell.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Oh! I'll be kinder than the Flower o'th' Sun,
Throw open all my Bosom and my Charms
To thy warm Joys.

sp.speaker: Palm.
sp.l: My Life, my Soul, my Heaven! Imitating their last Scene.
What think you now, Sir Dottrell?

sp.speaker: Sir Dott.
sp.p: and was it you, ye young Rogue!

sp.speaker: Palm.
sp.p: Even I, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Dott.
sp.p: But hadst thou the Heart to put thy poor Master into that wicked Fright!

sp.speaker: Palm.
sp.p: All my young Mistress's Design; she drew me into the Plot, and I had not the Power to refuse a fair Lady.

sp.speaker: Sir Dott.
sp.p: No, you young Smirker! Well, I am the happiest old Toast in three Kingdoms: Such a Wife, and such a Servant; there are not the Fellows of 'em in the whole Town, from one End to th' other; Uds bud, not from Knaves-Acre to Cuckolds-Point.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: And now, to shew you, Sir, how much I relish▪
The welcome Joys of being a happy Bride,
I have prepar'd a Bridal Entertainment;
A Marriage-Masque, Sir Dottrell.

sp.speaker: Sir Dott.
sp.p: How! A Masque!

div.head: The Ceremony of a Nuptial Entertainment perform'd. Mrs. Cross the Bride, and Mr. Leveridge the Bridegroom.
div.byline: The Musick set by Mr. D. Purcel.

lg.l: The Nymphs of the Plain,
And Swains of the Grove
All the whole Noble Train
Of Smiling Love:
A Jolly Jolly Troop in all our Pride,
Our happy Joys we'll summon;
To day we have made a Maid a Bride,
And to Night we shall make a Woman▪
Let the Blushing Miss,
That steals to the Bliss,
Take a whole Load of Shame upon her:
All the true Joys of Life
Are i'th' Arms of a Wife,
In Love's fair Bed of Honour.

sp.speaker: Chor.
sp.p: All the true Joys, &c.

sp.l: So now we have done the Work of the Day,
For the Work of the Night come all Hands away,
To lay the sweet Bride,
By her Bridegroom's Side:
To Bed, to Bed with the Bride.

sp.speaker: Bridegroom,
sp.l: Come, come, my dear Love, my Soul's all o' fire;
All burning Desire,
In thy Arms to expire;
To drink the sweet Nectar of Gods in Kisses,
And taste their whole Heav'n in Blisses.
Then come, come, come away.

sp.speaker: Bride,
sp.p: Oh, What shall I do!

sp.speaker: Bridegroom,
sp.p: Come, come, come away.

sp.speaker: Bride,
sp.l: Oh, How shall I go to a Man, to Bed!
I vow, I shall blush all Scarlet Red.

sp.speaker: Bridegroom,
sp.l: Prethee, prethee, bush
All Thoughts of a Blush.

sp.speaker: Bride,
sp.p: Nay, fye, naughty Man; what is't that you want?

sp.speaker: Bridegroom,
sp.l: All the warm sweet Blessings that Love can grant.
Then come, come, come.

sp.speaker: Bride,
sp.p: I can't, I can't.

sp.speaker: Bridegroom,
sp.p: Indeed, but you shall.

sp.speaker: Bride,
sp.p: I vow, but I sha'n't.

sp.speaker: Bridegroom,
sp.p: You must, you shall.

sp.speaker: Bride,
sp.p: I wont, I can't.

sp.speaker: Bridegroom,
sp.p: But come, come to Bed.

sp.speaker: Bride,
sp.p: I shall die with Shame.

sp.speaker: Bridegroom.
sp.l: Come, come, come away, and cast away Sorrow;
If thou blushest to night, thou wilt smile tomorrow.

sp.speaker: Bride,
sp.p: Oh, let me but lie one Night more alone.

sp.speaker: Bridegroom,
sp.p: No, no, no.

sp.speaker: Bride,
sp.p: Not one Night more a Maid!

sp.speaker: Bridegroom,
sp.p: Not one.

sp.speaker: Bride,
sp.l: Well, well; if I must, I'll try what I can.
But what shall I do to lie by a Man▪
You'll put out the Candle?

sp.speaker: Bridegroom,
sp.p: Ay, ay, ay, ay.

sp.speaker: Bride,
sp.p: And shut the Door?

sp.speaker: Bridegroom,
sp.p: Ay, ay, ay, ay.

sp.speaker: Bride,
sp.p: And shall no body see?

sp.speaker: Bridegroom,
sp.p: No, no body see.

sp.speaker: Bride,
sp.p: And no body hear?

sp.speaker: Bridegroom,
sp.p: No, none but we.

sp.speaker: Bride,
sp.l: Well, well; if I must, I'll try what I can.
But, what shall I do to lie by a Man!

sp.speaker: Chorus,
sp.l: All the true Joys of Life, &c.

sp.speaker: Sir D.
sp.p: I profess a most delicate Entertainment. But methinks that young Harlotry that pevish Tit of a Bride was a little too Coy when she should go to Bed. I hope, my Dear, thou wilt not serve me so.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: No, no, no.

sp.speaker: Sir D.
sp.p: Then come along my little Honey-suckle.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Hold, Stay, Sir Dottrell.— Sir, before I marry, I have a request which you must not deny me.

sp.speaker: Sir D.
sp.p: Deny thee, Child! I can deny thee nothing.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Then you must know I have made a solemn Vow never to marry that Man but he that shall steal me.

sp.speaker: Sir D.
sp.p: Steal thee!

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Ay, and this, Sir, you must promise me, I must confess 'twas a rash hasty Vow; but Vows when they are once made, are Sacred Things; and should I break them, Heaven would never bless me.

sp.speaker: Sir D.
sp.p: But why must I steal thee?

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.p: Oh fie, Sir Dottrell, what shrink at so small a piece of Knight Errantry, to win a Fair Lady.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p:
Besides, Sir Dottrell, I'll make it very easie; you Sir Dottrell, and your Man Shackarell shall come with a Ladder, to our Back-window, exactly at Twelve a Clock at Night. I'll steal the Keys of the Window, be ready to receive you, run into your Arms, trundle down the Ladder with you, knock up the Parson, slip into the Church, tumble o're the Matrimony, troll home
to my Father, tell him the whole story of the Frolick, whilst you sing He smiles, I laugh, and all the Bells of the Town ring Oh be Joyful.

sp.speaker: Sir D.
sp.p: Huzzah! why I'll do't; say no more, I'll do't. Steal thee! why I'll steal thee all; steal thy heart, steal to Bed to thee; steal into thy Bosom, steal into thy— Oh such Raptures! such Delight! How shall I contain me to the Wedding-night.

div.head: ACT V.
div.stage: Enter Sir Dottrell with a Dark Lanthorn, and Palmarin with a Ladder, which he sets up to the Balcony.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.p: See, Sir Dottrell, see, the Windows unlockt, the Cloud's opening▪ and your Dear Angel ready for descending. O you're a happy Man, Sir. But come aloft, Sir, mount the Walls, and Scale the Battlements.

sp.speaker: S. D.
sp.p: But I don't like this Night-work.— But be sure you hold the Ladder fast, for if it should slip, I should fall very heavy, for five thousand a year's a great weight, Shackarell!

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.p: Pox on you! you are one thousand a year heavier of my Money.

sp.speaker: S. D.
sp.p: [Upon the Balcone.] Now, Sirrah, stay you there, and watch till I come down again.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.p: Ay faith; I shall watch you!— Hst, where are you?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Here, Sir. Enter a Boy with a Bellman's Habit, Lanthorn, &c. Palmerin dresses himself as a Bellman. Exit Boy.

sp.speaker: Pal.

l.hi: All you that on your Beds lye waking,
To keep your Gity-brows from aking.

sp.l: First watch your Wives, and then your Money;

l.hi: And drive the Hornets from your Honey.
For fear your Spouse your Crabs inoculate,

sp.l: Keep her from Beaus and House of Chocolate.

l.hi: Preserve your Lambs from sly Court Foxes.

sp.l: From Hackney Coach with Wooden-windows.

l.hi: From Love abroad, and none within doors.

sp.p: Good Morrow my Masters all, Good Morrow: Past Twelve a Clock, and a warm Frosty Morning.— Ha! a Ladder at Mr. Deputies Back-window— Why, Sir, Mr. Deputy.— Your House is broken open. Thieves, Thieves, Thieves.

div.stage: Enter Sir Dottrell, and Jacintha in her Night-Gown.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Thieves, Thieves, Thieves!

sp.speaker: S. D.
sp.p: Why 'tis I Child, Sir Dottrell.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Sir Devil!

sp.speaker: S. D.
sp.p: Why, Chicken, I am come to Steal thee.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Steal me, Impudence! Thieves, Thieves, Thieves!

div.stage: Enter Mr. Deputy in his Night-Gown above.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dep.
sp.l: Ha! my Window broke open!—

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Ay, and your House broke open! your Great Trunk broke open.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dep.
sp.p: My Great Trunk!

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: And your Cabinet of Diamonds.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dep.
sp.p: My Diamonds! Exit from above.

sp.speaker: S. D.
sp.p: Why, Madam, what do you mean! What are you going to do! I hope you have more Conscience than to serve me thus?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Just as you deserve, Mr. Thief— Here slip this Casket of Diamonds into your Pocket. Giving a Casket to Palmerin.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dep.
sp.p: Rob'd, ruin'd, undone! A Casket of Jewels bought of my Lord Squanderland for 6000 Pound, and worth 10000. Lost, undone! ruin'd.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Ay, Sir, see there the Barbarous Thief.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dep.
sp.p: Sir Dottrell. See there.

sp.speaker: S. D.
sp.p: Ay, Sir, 'tis I.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dep.
sp.p: You, Sir, Dottrell.

sp.speaker: S. D.
sp.p: Yes, I Sir? what a Pox is't such a wonderment to see an Old Rat in a young Mouse-trap.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dep.
sp.p: I can't believe my Eyes.

sp.speaker: S. D.
sp.p: No, nor your Ears neither, if that young Witch has the handling of'em.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.p: Oh, Sir, Sir, yonder's my Lord Chief Justice come from Council at Whitehall, just turn'd the Corner o'th' Street in his Coach; what if I call him to hear the whole Business?

sp.speaker: S. D.
sp.p: My Lord Chief Justice!

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Ay, Sir, let him be call'd, let me have Justice against that Barbarous Riffler of your House. Now you may see how you've betray'd and ruin'd me. Made me dispose my heart to that base Man. That came not hither for the Love of me. 'Twas not the Charms of all my Youth and Beauty; My blooming Virtue, and my Virgin Innocence.

sp.speaker: S. D.
sp.p: Oh Woman, woman, woman!

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: No: 'twas the sparkling Luster of your Jewels that dazled in his Eyes.

sp.speaker: S. D.
sp.p: Was ever such a Traytress! Oh, Sir, believe her not one word; 'tis all Design, Plot, Treason, upon my Honour and my Life, Sir; and she has no mercy than a Weaver at an East-India-House. That wheedling dissembling young Imp there told me she had made a Vow to Marry no Man but he that should steal her; and I like an old blind dunce—

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Steal me! Bless my Ears! what says the Man! Steal me! Oh, Sir, Dottrell, Sir Dottrell, this is like the rest of all your Barbarous Usage.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dep.
sp.p: Ay, Child, steal thee!

sp.speaker: S. D.
sp.l: Ay Sir, steal her! I tell you, Sir, once more, that Monster—

sp.speaker: Mr. Dep.
sp.p: Ay, you may tell me what you please: You that can do such wicked things, can have the confidence to say any thing. Enter Palmerin as Lord Chief Justice, his Train born up by his Clark. My Noble Lord! I beg your Lordships pardon for giving you this trouble at this unseasonable time of Night.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.p: Justice is never troublesome nor unseasonable, we are bound to right the injured.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dep.
sp.p: Injur'd! Ay my Lord, I have had [A Chair set forth and Palm. sits.] my House broke open. I have been rob'd, my Lord, rob'd of a Casket of Jewels price 6000 l.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.p: Six thousand Pound!

sp.speaker: Mr. Dep.
sp.p: See there the Ladder, and see here the Thief.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.p: Sir Dottrell!

sp.speaker: S. Dot.
sp.p: I shall run mad; that's certain.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.p: The Worshipful Sir Dottrell, I am all amazement.

sp.speaker: S. Dot.
sp.p: Amaz'd my Lord, Ay and amaz'd, and amaz'd again, when you have heard the whole Roguery. Your Lordship is a Good Man, and an Honourable man, and will do me Justice; I desire you to hear me, my Lord; I'll tell you the whole truth from the Top to the Bottom. I'll confess all my Lord.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.p: Confess! you can't do better Sir Dottrell.

sp.speaker: Sir Dot.
sp.p: Then in the first place I am a wheizing, grunting, empty-headed old Sot of Fourscore.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.p: Very good.

sp.speaker: Sir Dot.
sp.p: In the next place, having no more Grace than Brains, and no more Fear before my Eyes than to—

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.p: Break open a House.

sp.speaker: Sir Dot.
sp.p: Break open a House! No my Lord, break a fools head of my own, to run my reverend But-end a tilt at a Gay Petticoat, and play the old Game of hard heads call'd Matrimony.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.p: Very well. Go on, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Dot.
sp.p: An old doating fool to have no more sense at these years than to pretend to make Womans Meat, when I am more fit for Worms-meat, my Lord. To be hankering after Young Flesh, when I am going the way of all flesh; and thus by the wicked instigation of the World, the Devil, and dry Bones, my Lord, with one Leg in my Grave I had no more Conscience than think of slipping the other to Bed to a Girl of Nineteen; and to lay my old Frost and Night-cap by her young Fruze and Top-knot.

sp.speaker: Palm.
sp.p: And so falling in Love with a young Lady, and having a particular occasion for a Necklace of Pearl, Locket of Diamonds, and some other Toys, to the Value of Six Thousand Pounds, for a Present to your Young Mistress, you made bold with Mr. Deputy.

sp.speaker: Sir Dott.
sp.p: I know nothing of Mr. Deputy's Lockets and Diamonds. I had no Design but upon that precious Jewel his Daughter there; that young Fury with her Snakes in Powder and Curl; that Cloven-foot in Lac'd Shooes, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Palm.
sp.p: Ha! What's all this?

sp.speaker: Sir Dott.
sp.p: A wicked and notorious Jezabel, that has conspir'd the Ruine, Fall and Destruction of the Right Worshipful Sir Dottrel.

sp.speaker: Palm.
sp.p: Yet hold, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Dott.
sp.p:
I cannot hold. I must confess my Sins, and repent, my Lord; and tell your Lordship, I have been galloping Headlong in the fair Road to the Devil, my Lord. For an Old Coxcomb of Eighty Eight, that has no more Wit than to Marry a Young Girl of Eighteen, heaps more Coals upon his Head
than another City Conflagration; and ought to be Marry'd on no Day but the Second of September, my Lord. For when the Firebrands of Whoredom and Cuckoldom are once lighted, they are unquencheable; and a Young Gipsie that takes Fire in her Pudding-Lane, is never to be stopt till she burns down to Bridewell, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Palm.
sp.p: How now! Ill-manner'd, Sir! Do you know where you are? This Insolence before the Bar of Justice! Ha!

sp.speaker: Sir Dott.
sp.p: I beg your Lordship's Pardon.

sp.speaker: Palm.
sp.p: Better Language, and more Civility.

sp.speaker: Sir Dott.
sp.p: I have done, Sir. I know no Harm of the poor Girl. She is a Good Girl, and an Honest Girl, and a Religious Girl— Why, I have heard her at her Prayers, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Palm.
sp.p: No more trifling, Sir. If you have any thing to say, speak home to the purpose. Has this young Lady done you any Wrong any Injustice, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Dott.
sp.p: Wrong! O Lord, no! She has done me a great deal of Right, my Lord. Alas, Sir, I have been an impertinent Old Fool, and have so tired and teized her, and haunted her, till the poor Thing, in her own Defence, when I would take no Warning, and receive no denial, has only drawn me into a Plot, Sir; to see my Back-side, Sir; to get a fair Riddance of me, by sending me up High Holborn, and please your Lordship: I vow and swear that's all.

sp.speaker: Palm.
sp.p: And did she draw you into this Plot?

sp.speaker: Sir Dott.
sp.p: She, Sir; Ay, ay. Why, I broke open her Father's House by her own Special Command.

sp.speaker: Palm.
sp.l: Very pretty! And so in Obedience to a fair Lady—

sp.speaker: Sir Dott.
sp.p: Ay, Sir.

sp.speaker: Palm.
sp.p: To rid her of a troublesom old Blockhead.

sp.speaker: Sir Dott.
sp.p: Right, Sir.

sp.speaker: Palm.
sp.p: You committed Burglary.

sp.speaker: Sir Dott.
sp.p: Very true, Sir.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.p: In pure Complaisance to be hang'd out of the way.

sp.speaker: Sir Dott.
sp.p: Why truly, Sir, if that False Peacher can Swear me or Lie me into a Halter, I shall be hang'd and hang'd, and double hang'd, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Palm.
sp.p: Oh, I have heard too much a plain Confession: Dead, gone, lost!

sp.speaker: Sir Dott.
sp.p: Dead, Sir!

sp.speaker: Palm.
sp.p: The World can't save ye.

sp.speaker: Sir Dott.
sp.p: How! Not save me!

sp.speaker: Palm.
sp.p: Impossible! Oh Sir Dottrel, Sir Dottrel! A Man of your Estate, a Person of your Worth, for you to run yourself into this hideous Sin— Oh, 'tis unpardonable! A Common Thief! Poor Rogues, that break a House for want, for Bread for Hunger, those pitied Wretches might find some Beams of Grace: But you, Sir Dottrel; Oh, there's no Hopes, no Mercy!

sp.speaker: Sir Dott.
sp.p: What do you mean, Sir? I hope you don't intend to hang me.

sp.speaker: Palm.
sp.p: Had you a Thousand Lives, all, all lost.

sp.speaker: Sir Dott.
sp.p: Oh, my Dear Lord, don't fright me! Hang an Alderman! Hang a Gold Chain! I shall never be able to bear it. Oh, my dear Lord, upon my Knees I do beseech you.

sp.speaker: Palm.
sp.p: Kneel, Sir, to Heaven, not me; make your Peace there, Sir Dottrel.

sp.speaker: Sir Dott.
sp.p: Oh, don't talk of Heaven! I tremble at the Name on't. And, Madam, dear Madam, save me, save me. Dear Honey, sweet Devil, speak Truth but this once in thy whole Life, and tell my Lord the whole Story. Dear Rogue, don't let me be hang'd: Besides, I shall make but a sneaking Dog in a String; and thou'lt get no Credit by Hanging me.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Nay; why do you trouble me?

sp.speaker: Sir Dott.
sp.p: I'll never trouble thee again: I'll quit thee, resign thee, renounce thee for ever. And therefore, sweet little Tygress, speak a good Word to my Lord: Save but my Life, and I'll give thee half my Estate.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: How, Sir!

sp.speaker: Sir Dote.
sp.p: Half my Estate.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: My Lord, do you hear how the poor Man begs for Life? If your Lordship can do any thing for him—

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Do you desire it, Madam?

sp.speaker: Sir Dott.
sp.p: Ay, she does desire it; she must desire it.

sp.speaker: Palm.
sp.l: Nay, Madam, your Commands—

sp.speaker: Sir Dott.
sp.p: O sweet Rogue!

sp.speaker: Palm.
sp.p: Well, Sir Dottrel, for this fair Lady's sake I'll try what I can do for you. But fie, Sir Dottrel, half your Estate! That's too much: You shall have Mercy at a cheaper Price.

sp.speaker: Sir Dott.
sp.p: Oh, you're a good Man.

sp.speaker: Palm.
sp.p: But first, Sir Dottrel, have not you an Estate of young Palmerin Worthy's, bought of his Prodigal Brother.

sp.speaker: Sir Dott.
sp.p: I have, Sir.

sp.speaker: Palm.
sp.p: And I warrant you, did not give half the Worth sor't.

sp.speaker: Sir Dott.
sp.p: Not a Quarter.

sp.speaker: Palm.
sp.p: Then upon Condition that, before all these Witnesses, you'll give it under your Hand and Seal, to return that Estate to young Palmerin, I'll promise you your Life.

sp.speaker: Sir Dott.
sp.p: With all my Heart, Sir.

sp.speaker: Palm.
sp.p: Here's my Clark then shall draw up the Agreement.

sp.speaker: Sir Dott.
sp.p: Ay, my Lord, you shall have it under Hand, Seal, Bill, Bond, Judgment, Statute; any thing for a sweet Life, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Well now, Sir Dottrel, I hope I am not that hard hearted Thing; you see I am all Tenderness, all melting Pity; so very kind—

sp.speaker: Sir Dott.
sp.p: Kind! Ay, Pox on thee, thou'rt damnable kind!

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: How, Sir!

sp.speaker: Sir Dott.
sp.p: Heav'ns bless thee, I would say. Kind Chicken! Ay, very kind; a dear sweet Rogue.

sp.speaker: Palm.
sp.p: Come, Sir Dottrel, your Hand.

sp.speaker: Sir Dott.
sp.p: Ay, both my Hands. Signs and Seals.

sp.speaker: Palm.
sp.p: You deliver this as your Act and Deed to the Use of Palmerin Worthy.

sp.speaker: Sir Dott.
sp.p: To the Use of Palmerin Worthy.

sp.speaker: Palm.
sp.p: So; now to perform my Part. In the first place, Mr. Deputy, to make Peaee with you, Sir Dottrel heartily begs your Pardon, and by my Hand restores your Jewels, [gives Mr. Deputy the Casket.] In the next place, to remove all Fears and Jealousies of a Bench and Judges; instead of that terrible thing call'd a Lord Chief Justiee, I am that harmless poor Creature, your Honest Man Shackarell.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Shackarell!

sp.speaker: Palm.
sp.p:
No; no Shackarell neither: For instead of your Man Shakarell, I am
your Rival Palmarin; no more yours, but this Lady's Humble Servant.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Palmerin!

sp.speaker: Palm.
sp.l: And now, Mr. Deputy—

sp.speaker: Mr. Dep.
sp.p: Palmarin▪ Worthy!

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.p: As kind Fortune has at last removed all Obstacles to my Honourable Pretensions to the Fair Jacintha; as this kind Knight has given me one Estate, I hope you'll give me another, your Beautiful Daughter, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dep.
sp.p: Ay, with all my Heart and Soul. Take her, dear Boy, take her, and Heav'n bless thee with her. Young Palmerin, and a Thousand a Year! Thou art such an ingenious young Rogue, thou deservd'st a Girl with her Weight in Diamonds.

sp.speaker: Sir Dott.
sp.p: Here's fine Work.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dep.
sp.p: Go, take her to Church, take her to thy Arms, take her to Bed; and get me Grandsons and Great Grandsons. How shall I mend my dull City-Breed with such a Wit for my Son-in-law!

sp.speaker: Sir Dott.
sp.p: And art not thou a Perjur'd Devil?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Perjur'd! No, not at all.

sp.speaker: Sir Dott.
sp.p: No, young Deceiver? Where's the Promise you made me?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: I have perform'd 'em.
Yes, Sir; I promis'd ye before this Honest Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Sir Dott.
sp.p: Honest with a Vengeance!

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Sir Dottrel was the Man of the whole World
Should make me the happiest and best Wife in Christendom,
And I have kept that Promise: For Sir Dottrel
Has given my Palmerin an Estate, and that
Estate has given me Palmerin. And thus
(Upon my Knees I thank you.) You have made me
That best, that happiest Wife—

sp.speaker: Sir Dott.
sp.p: I can bear no longer. Going away.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Yet, stay, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Dott.
sp.p: Stay, Tormenter!

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Ay, Sir; stay— I have a Boon to ask you.
That you'd forgive me.
Ay, Sir; forgive me: Do. I beg it of you.
I own my Faults; own I have us'd you hardly.
And yet I never wrong'd you.

sp.speaker: Sir Dott.
sp.p: How! Not wrong'd me!

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: No, Sir; not wrong'd you: I have lov'd ye more
In cheating you, than marrying you. Consider
What 'twas you ask'd; and what I have deny'd.
Marriage, alas! Sir Dottrell, had undone ye:
To take a Wife, were that Rack Rent upon ye▪
Your Age could never pay. Let such Grey Hairs
Go not to Church to Wedlock, but to Prayers,
And kneel to Heaven, not Woman, at those years.

sp.speaker: Sir Dott.
sp.l: In troth, thou art in the right on't. I confess.
In thy soft Arms I should have slept so sweetly—
And Sleeping had been all; nay, and, perhaps, not that too.
I should have spit, and cough'd, and wheiz'd, and grunted;
Made but a slovenly Husband for a young Wife.
And therefore, Palmerin, give me thy Hand—
And thine, Jacintha— Now, if I could but out with it—

sp.speaker: Palm.
sp.p: Speak boldly.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Resign me nobly.

sp.speaker: Palm.
sp.p: Do a generous Deed.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: And think what Glorious Triumph you will make:
'Tis brave to give, when it is poor to take.

sp.speaker: Sir Dott.
sp.l: Then take her, and be happy— But, I vow,
It almost breaks my Heart, that I must lose thee.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Nay, dry your Eyes. I will do more than love ye.
What though I cannot give a Hand, (for that's
My Palmerin's;) I'll give you both my Knees.
I'll pray for you to my last Hour of Life.

sp.speaker: Sir Dott.
sp.p: And wilt thou pray for me?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: More than a Father.
He gave me Birth: But you have given me Palmerin.

sp.speaker: Sir Dott.
sp.l: Yes, thou shalt pray for me: For I'll do something
As shall deserve thy Prayers. Here, Palmerin;
To thy own Estate, I have given thee, take mine too.
For, since I must not make my dear Jacintha
My Wife, my Heir I'll make thee. No Old Age,
Nor no Young Rival shall debar me that.
My Fortunes, Treasures, Jewels: Five fair Lordships;
Twice five fair Thousand Acres;
And thrice as many Pounds in fairer Gold,
Is all thy own. Give but a poor Old Man
My Length and Breadth in Clay, when I am Dust;
And all the rest, my dear Jacintha, 's thine.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Oh, this amazing Kindness! Let me kneel once more:
Too poor in Thanks to pay this wondrous Goodness.

sp.speaker: Palm.
sp.p: Too poor, indeed.

sp.speaker: Sir Dott.
sp.l: Nay, fye; dear Shackarel, rise.
Thou art the happy Lord of fair Jacintha,
And I am thy Servant now— And rise Jacintha, rise.
Come, Mr. Deputy; we'll both be Fathers now.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dep.
sp.p: Yes, I the happiest, you the kindest Father.

sp.speaker: Sir Dott.
sp.l: Come, thou sweet Bride that must be, we'll prepare
The Wedding-Dinner: Shall we not?
We'll have the Poets, and the Fiddles too,
And all the Wedding Joys. I shall be pleas'd
To see young Palmerin the happy Man:
Nay, I'll dance too, as heartily as I can. Exeunt.

div.stage: Being a Prospect of Terras Walks on Eight several Stages mounted one above another, each Stage contains a Range of Stone-work extending from side to side, decorated with Paintings in Fresco of Heroick History; over each Piece of Painting are carved Rails and Banisters with Pedestals: On Thirty Two Pedestals are planted Sixteen Golden Flower-Pots, and Sixteen Statues of Gods and Goddesses, viz. Jupiter and Juno; Apollo and Diana; Mars and Venus; Neptune and Thetis; Pallas and Mercury; Bacchus and Ceres; Hercules and Flora; Cupid and Psyche. Through the Center, and advancing Twenty Four Foot high, is an Ascent of Marble Steps. This Sett of Scenes is encompass'd round with Arborage-work, circled round with double Festoons of Flowers tyed up in Ribbons of Gold, terminating at Fifty Foot deep, being the Extent of the House, with a Prospect of a Garden above the highest Terras.
Above Fifty Figures are seen upon the several Terras's, some of which Descend upon the Stage for the Entertainment.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cross,
sp.l: COme Strephon, Phyllis come let's troll
A Jovial Hour away.
And whilst the Golden Minutes roll,
We'll Sing and Dance, and Play.

sp.speaker: Miss.
sp.l: See in the smiling Month of May,
The Songsters of the Grove they play,
Must such a poor young thing as they
A little Bird so very small
That just can tattle, chirp and prattle:
I can but sing, and Oh that's all.
But if I live till past fifteen,
See such fine Sparks as here are seen.
I fear, I fear, you'l teach me then
To perch and plume, and dress and pride,
And more than tattle,
Chirp and prattle,
I then shall sing and love beside.
Let Monarchs boast their High Renown;
A Garland's fairer than a Crown.
Whilst Courts have all the Pomp and noise,
The Groves have all the Sweets and Joys.
Then come kind Damon, come away,
To Cynthia's Bower advance;
The Sylvanes they shall Pipe and Play,
And we'll lead up the Dance.

lg.l: Hark, hark! To Pleasure and Delight
The Earth, the Seas, and Air invite:
The Winds, they whistle; Woods, they ring;
The Brooks, they murmur; Birds, they sing:
The Turtles coo; and Lambs, they play:
And why not we at blithe as they?
Then, whilst we trip it o'er o'er the Plain,
Let Pan and Flora live and reign:
We'll envy not great Jove; and be
As bless'd, though not as great as He.
But, see! Our Goddess does appear!
She comes to grace our Rural Choir:
Then let the Muses all inspire
Our Joys to a Sublimer Air.
Let her Great Name go round;
Yet louder let it sound.
Cynthia! a Name so proud,
To chant her endless Song,
Jove's Thunder's not too loud;
Eternity too long.

sp.speaker: Grand Chorus,
sp.l: Let her Great Name, &c.

sp.speaker: Hains.
sp.p: Well, Sir; and what think you of our New World in the Moon?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Why, Faith, Jo, I think, as your Painter has dress'd it, 'tis a new World indeed.

sp.speaker: Hains.
sp.p: And how do you like it?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: As I do a Mistress the better for being a new one.
New Objects still new Appetites must raise,
And an Original Beauty sure may please.

div.head: EPILOGUE,
div.byline: Spoke by Miss Dennis Chock, Dress'd with a great Wig like a Beau.
div.stage: She Enters Singing Part of an Old Tune.

sp.l: Gallants,
THE Author sends me here, to win your Hearts
With this full Wig, and not his own Deserts;
For he believes, and I suppose you know,
There's nothing pleases more than a young Beau.
But yet the Stage this day has done its best;
For it has furnish'd out a Miser's Feast:
And if this Charge and Pains should now be lost,
'Twere hard to Shipwrack on a Golden Coast.
But, Gentlemen and Ladies, I must say,
Since I am chose Champion to defend this Play,
I'll do't: Draws her Sword.
And here, with Sword in Hand, declare
To justifie it, against all that dare
Strive to undo the Painter, and the Player.
The Poet, he, alas! only depends
On your Good Nature, to become his Friends.
But now, perhaps, you may believe I fear
To see this naked Weapon. But I swear
I'd fight our Foes, did I not too well know
'Twould spoil my Character of being a Beau.
Therefore, since I'm good natur'd, be you kind;
For, rat me, Gentlemen, 'twas well design'd.
But, Pax upon 'em, 'tis all home-spun Cloth;
All from an English Web, and English Growth.
But if we'd let it make a costly Dance
To Paris, and bring home some Scenes from France,
I'm sure 'twou'd take: For you, Gadzooks, are civil;
And wish them well, that wish you at the Devil.
